name: Trier
fun_fact: Fun fact: Founded in 17 BC as Augusta Treverorum, Trier is Germany's oldest city. The Porta Nigra (Black Gate from 170 AD) is held together by just a few iron rods and gravity - no mortar! In 1030, a Greek monk named Simeon had himself locked inside the gate to become a hermit. After his death and canonization, the gate was converted into a double church, which ironically saved it from being demolished for building materials like other Roman structures.

hero_dishes.name: Trierer Schwenksteak
hero_dishes.description: Marinated pork steak, often enjoyed with a refreshing glass of Mosel Riesling wine
hero_dishes.origin_story: A local Trier delicacy that showcases the region's pork traditions paired with the world-famous wines from the Mosel Valley. Trier sits in the oldest wine-growing area in Germany, and this pairing represents centuries of culinary heritage.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Traditional restaurants throughout Trier's old town, especially wine taverns serving regional specialties

hero_dishes.description: Spit-roasted pork with traditional German accompaniments
hero_dishes.origin_story: A classic preparation method that dates back to medieval times in the Rhineland-Palatinate region. The slow roasting creates tender, flavorful meat that pairs perfectly with local Riesling.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Alt-Trier in the Old Town (serves classic dishes with local beers), traditional German restaurants

hero_dishes.name: Blutwurst with Apple Compote
hero_dishes.description: Blood sausage served with fried potatoes and sweet apple compote
hero_dishes.origin_story: A traditional Rhineland dish that balances the rich, savory sausage with the sweetness of apples - a classic German flavor combination that reflects resourceful use of all parts of the animal.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Traditional German restaurants like Alt-Trier and local Gasthauses

hero_dishes.name: Mosel Wine-Marinated Pomace Meat
hero_dishes.description: Tender, aromatic roast marinated for days in wine-pomace broth
hero_dishes.origin_story: The most famous Mosel specialty, this dish reflects the region's wine heritage. In modern Mosel cuisine, the meat is marinated for days in fine wine-pomace broth until it acquires incomparable flavor - a technique influenced by Mediterranean and French haute cuisine since Roman times.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Weinwirtschaft Friedrich-Wilhelm (wine restaurant in city center), Weinstube Kesselstatt (650-year-old wine tradition)

signature_drinks.name: Mosel Riesling Wine
signature_drinks.description: World-famous white wine from the Mosel Valley, offering ideal conditions for growing Riesling grapes
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Trier is the largest city in the Mosel Valley and serves as the 'Wine Capital of the Mosel.' Wine cellars offer guided tastings where you can learn about local viticulture. Vereinigte Hospitien has Germany's oldest wine cellar dating back to Roman times.

signature_drinks.name: Viez (Apple Wine)
signature_drinks.description: Traditional apple cider with high proportion of wooden apples, giving it a tart taste (5.5-6.5% alcohol)
signature_drinks.origin_story: Around Trier and the Saar region, apples supply this 'national drink.' UNESCO designated Viez as intangible cultural heritage in 2024. Traditionally served in the 'Poarz' - a white stone jug.
signature_drinks.where_to_find: Cubiculum (casual cellar pub great for Viez), served pure or mixed with cola, sparkling water, or lemonade in many restaurants
